Expectation1: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation1: A pilot declares low fuel on approach and needs immediate vectors to the nearest runway.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: The headset pressed tight against my ears as the pilot’s voice crackled through, tense and urgent: “Mayday, mayday, low fuel, requesting immediate vectors.” My eyes darted across the radar, calculating the safest, quickest path to the nearest runway. Every second counted. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder—my volunteer shift started in ten minutes. I was the only one scheduled to unlock the community center, and I knew people were already waiting outside, relying on me to open the doors and start the morning service. My supervisor at the center had stressed the importance of punctuality, especially today. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in: the lives in the sky depending on my calm, precise instructions, and the hopeful faces outside the facility, counting on my presence. My heart pounded as I stared at the clock, torn between the urgent needs of strangers in the air and the expectations of those waiting on the ground.
